Award.AwardTitle: CC-NIE Integration: Science Slices Converting Network Research Innovation into Enhanced Capability for Computational Science and Engineering at the University of Utah

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
As demands on campus networks - many driven by science and engineering disciplines - intensify, traditional network management approaches are increasingly obsolete. Researchers often require network paths with higher throughput, increased security, and/or perimeter firewall bypass. Network operators traditionally have accommodated a few research users by provisioning dedicated resources. Previous approaches for addressing requests for special connectivity to regional and national facilities have not scaled well.

At the University of Utah, a research team is upgrading part of the campus network with technology originally developed for a national network research testbed (NSF GENI). This "sliceable network" model allows multiple virtual networks to be established in parallel over the same equipment. Each resulting science slice may have different characteristics and may connect to distinct resources either on or off campus. This allocation scheme may incorporate computational and storage resources in addition to network paths. With hardware supporting emerging Software Defined Networking standards, these slices can be controlled to very fine granularity. This technology inherently supports dynamic slice creation to enable on-demand network resource allocation for researchers.

This work provides an abstraction to insulate multiple high-intensity users cleanly in a campus network. The ensuing intellectual merit follows from applying a research focused network management approach more broadly to part of a large production environment. For broader impact, a connection to the University?s undergraduate honors residence allows this innovative cohort to interact directly with the sliced network and also pursue guided experimentation. The core software base and project-specific enhancements are available under open-source licensing.

POR.DRECONTENT:
As the demands on campus networks, mainly driven by domain sciences, become more complex, traditional network management approaches are becoming obsolete. Users require network paths with higher bandwidth, increased security, or exemption from campus firewall rules. Campus network operators historically have accommodated a few users through dedicated virtual or physical resources. Current trends in scientific instrumentation enable more scientists to deploy genome sequencers and compute and storage resources of their own. Inevitably, these local resources require connectivity with regional and/or national facilities. The result is that requests from researchers for special network treatment are becoming more numerous, more complex, and more diverse. Current methods of addressing these requests do not scale, thus some campus network users are underserved with little prospect for future improvement.
To address these concerns in this project we applied network virtualization techniques to dedicated sections of the network. These virtualization techniques allowed the campus research team to explore the application of different security, network, and performance characteristics to multiple sections of the campus.
In the data center section of the network, these virtualization techniques allowed for multiple dynamic dedicated high performance paths in/out of the data center.  These dynamic paths have provided isolated containers for experiments in areas such as, security, high performance data transfers, and network protocol development.  These paths have also provided production quality containers for high performance transfers for different science domains such as, astronomy, genomics, and chemical engineering. Both the experimental and production paths have enabled the respective science disciplines at local, regional and national scale. 
In the campus sections of the network, the research team has used these network virtualization techniques to explore different security techniques at a fine grained level. Specifically, we developed a dynamic policy driven network access control approach. In this framework, access control policies are expressed in a systematic policy specification, which is consumed by a software defined networking (SDN) controller, to directly drive low level realization of those policies. This work, along with other work in network management, has allowed the research group to expand its scope and explore forays into network security and management based on knowledge collected from the network itself, security tools, and live network patterns of users. In order to obtain more realistic feedback and to validate the initial findings, the research group has worked with campus engineers to start to migrate the techniques out of the lab and into real-world prototypes.
